caption: A museum contained inside the hotel de Invalides, showing relief maps of military importance throughout the 1700s. These are essentially large table sized models of towns and the castles. Many coastal French towns needed to defend themselves against the English and Dutch Navies, so Islands points and river mouths were defended with Forts, and mapped out in models, so that the generals in Paris could strategize.

Meticulous models of various forts, castles and walled city of France. Really interesting. Too bad it gets crowded and noisy with too many children running around not even paying attention to what it is there. Also it needed better care and maintenance as many signs / maps were scratched and it doesnt seem anyone is paying attention

Take a hike on the fourth floor of the French army museum. You will find some highly interesting things related to strategic models of quite a few fortresses and cities. With a bit of assistance the wheelchair was no problem and there is some interactivity for a younger audience. In the same complex you will find Napoleon's tomb as well as Vauban's and Turenne's. Excellent giftshop and very friendly people offering coffee etc.

This is a hidden gem that I bet not many people visit. I thought it was very cool - also literally cool, when the rest of the building was kind of stuffy on this warm, humid day, the 4th floor was cool and comfortable.
Fascinating models of fortified cities in France dating from around 1700. It's hidden on the top floor and in a small-ish room but definitely worth the visit.
Awesome visit, so cool to see these maps. The interactive program with the map of Bayonne blew me away, so cool.

As I doubt I will ever get to tour the old forts that protected France, the opportunity to see these very detailed models was great.  The amount of effort and skill required to create each model is extraordinary, to be sure.  Yes, they are at the top of four flights of stairs. The good news is that there are other great museums to see on each floor on the way up, so the trip can be made in segments.  Enjoy!

Amazing museum and a hidden gem for sure ðŸ’Ž It's incredible how the brilliance of military defense strategy was built upon knowing Maps. Why was Napoleon able to analyze maps in a way that his adversaries could not? ðŸ¤”
Never seen something like this in a museum. Very interesting! The level of detail is incredible

"Find me," my wife said, "a small, quirky museum." I succeed. Ignoring the other rooms on our ascent of the stairs, we arrived at the Plans-Reliefs and it was everything I'd hoped. Dark, detailed, beautifully designed and minimal (in terms of the exhibit enclosures), and almost completely deserted. I think there was one other couple in there the whole time we looked, enthralled, at these exquisite models. They were designed and realized to leave no detail un-noted, because their defensive purpose required it. There is a sense in these reliefs of how life was actually lived in the 18th and 19th century in rural and urban France. With detailing at the level of hedgerows and farmhouses, one could move around the exhibits and imagine people moving through the landscape. It was a lovely moment of quiet and contemplation during a really delightful visit to Paris. I should note that my wife is an architect, and I share her fascination and enthusiasm for perfectly detailed models, so this choice was perfect for us. Not everyone may find this attention to detail in a calm quiet setting as gripping as we did, but for those who might, I cannot recommend this wonderful museum highly enough.

Surprising, interesting and fun! Slightly tucked away in the attic of the HÃ´tel des Invalides is a collection of plan reliefs (3d models of cities) whose origins date back to 1668, when the Marquis de Louvois, Louis XIV's Minister of War, had a number of 3D models built in preparation for sieges and wars. In the centuries that followed, the collection grew further: of the 260 models manufactured between 1668 and 1870, 112 are now on display.
Unfortunately, there are no English translations, but thankfully, I had google Translate installed. Incredible 3d maps of forts and strongholds
Very cool, uncrowded museum with fascinating 3 dimensional maps that are like the most elaborate and well made dioramas you can see.
Very cool
Absolutely extraordinary models. Nice captioning and interactive screens for the most complex. Could have spent hours looking at them.
Everyone interested in military history should go there! Tons of incredibly interesting items related to war. You can see how much effort humanity put into killing itself.
Include 4-5 sections. The 4th floor is my favorite. Many cities model

I find this type of subject to be quiet interesting to see. Yet I found the area to be so dark with weird lighting that it feels like I was in an abandoned hospital hallway complete with terrifying spotlights.
The scale and detail of the models is amazing, expansive collection of ~20 scale models of fortified cities.
I love this stuff and it is well preserved.
Beautiful museum.
A must see if you are visiting the museum - gives a great insight into the topology of Paris
If you spend time to see Tomb of Napoleon please take additional time to see this remarkable place.
Very good place to see the development of the french army and also french history. Very good visit
Ok
An excellent and amazing sight to see, absolutely worth a visit!
Just beautiful structure and historic
So neat!
Excellent
Great extension
Very nice place

The museum that I like the most in the Les Invalides complex. Contains models of border cities, forts, battlefields and other important places from a strategic or military point of view, at 1/600 scale. They were created from the time of Louis XIV, and although many have been lost, the museum displays a third of the complete collection.

Visited during heritage days and yet no wait and few people in this beautiful, unexpected museum that I had not heard of! Very beautiful models, what realism, what work of art. Congratulations to the artisans and the museum team!!  Ps: I had fun looking for a good 1/4 hour for the entrance to Mont St Michel given the complexity of the monument :)

This notice is only for the museum's website. Why are there so many dead links, the video of the construction of a fortified castle no longer exists, the list of plans is inaccessible, doesn't anyone care?? , or is there a curator involved in the project?  Gentle decision-makers, browse your site as an average person, you will have surprises.....clean it up....

The exhibits in each corner change depending on the season and events, but the diorama of French castles in the attic on the top floor has remained unchanged for 30 years since I first visited.  Most visitors don't come here, so you can fully enjoy the know-how of sieges to your heart's content.
Visiting this museum requires taking a global ticket for the entire museum, which is why I am removing one star. Otherwise this exhibition is magnificent.

I loved this part of the museum, a set of relief maps at 1/600 including certain cities like Toulon or Bayonne. A short, free 10-minute guided tour allows you to fully understand and have a little more context.

A moving place which shows us the work of soldiers, cartographers and model makers of the 16th century. The place which belongs to the Ministry of Culture, in an army place, is well staged, the staff is competent and willingly answers your questions. Be careful, it's only one floor with a few models, the visit is quick.
